author: Anna Molin
title: Nobel Prize in medicine goes to those fighting parasites, malaria
text:
STOCKHOLM — Scientists from Ireland, Japan and China won this year’s Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discoveries relating to therapies against infections caused by roundworm parasites and malaria.
Irish-born scientist William C. Campbell and Japanese-born Satoshi Ōmura discovered a new drug, Avermectin, which has radically lowered incidences of River Blindness and Lymphatic Filariasis, two diseases caused by parasitic worms, and showed efficacy against a number of other parasitic diseases, the Nobel Assembly said in a statement.
Chinese-born Youyou Tu discovered Artemisinin, a drug that has significantly reduced mortality rates for patients suffering from Malaria.
Their discoveries “have provided humankind with powerful new means to combat these debilitating diseases that affect hundreds of millions of people annually,” the Nobel Assembly said.
Campbell is a research fellow emeritus at Drew University, Madison, New Jersey; Ōmura is professor emeritus at Kitasato University, Japan; and Tu is the chief professor at the China Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
An extended version of this story can be found at WSJ.com
